You know what's impressively rare? Having a high school science department in which every teacher holds a doctorate. This month, MRH's own Kathleen Dwyer, Ben Nims and Chuck McWilliams all successfully defended their dissertation in a collaborative, cohort-based program. They conducted their defense via Zoom video conference with UMSL Education staff due to COVID. Their work examined graduates of MRH High School. The dissertation was titled "The Development of Science Identity in Undergraduate STEM Majors: A Case Study of Urban High School Students."
Our heartiest congratulations to all!

MRH Middle/High at the Research and Design Center

- Facilitates salary negotiation workshops
- Works closely with local universities and other AAUW branches and organizations on issues such as Title IX, human trafficking, voter education, pay equity, and sexual harassment and discrimination.
Way to go Joy!

MRH Senior Takes High Honors in On-line Science Fair

MRH’s very own Kamau Muse Morris, a senior, has been named a semi-finalist in this year’s Academy of Science St. Louis Science Fair Honors Division.

The so-called E-Fair featured 605 projects by 862 students across the region. The students -- many of whom left their projects and log books inside closed classrooms -- completed their science fair entries in basements, bedrooms, and backyards. Kamau's project title: Do Circadian Rhythms Affect the Display of Intelligence Among Male Bumblebees (Bombus impatiens)?

He was one of just eight semi-finalists.

Major sponsors of the Academy of Science St. Louis Science Fair include Bayer and Boeing, with major support from Maryville University, St. Louis University, Washington University, and the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center.

Get set for your heartstrings to get tugged, after reading this note from ECC teacher Heather Bailey:

"I came across this flag in my basement. It's a symbol of a classroom community of first graders I had in 2008. That year, as we learned about government, the class decided we could form our own government. We started by designing this flag to represent ourselves. We moved onto creating a mission, laws, and consequences. (On the back of the flag, there's even a pocket containing our government handbook.)
Remembering the ideals of these young seven year olds, fills me with hope for our nation's future. I know these young adults will continue to care for others as they change the world. I'm sorry the world isn't as we thought it would be for your senior year, but I'm so thankful it's you who is graduating. Our world needs you, and we've been waiting a very long time. Congratulations on all of your hard work. I'm proud of you and who you've become.
Love,
Mrs. Bailey
P.S. I'd love to see pictures of you in the comments.

The proud members of Gateway2Change are presenting their 2019-20 project today at Emerson Co.

Gateway2Change was created in 2014 after the tragic events in Ferguson and has served more than 400 students representing 38 high schools throughout the St. Louis region. Annual groups of students participate in summits facilitated by program staff and community partners. Students explore how social and cultural differences influence individual life experiences and perspectives; and apply problem-solving models to develop solutions for issues related to diversity and equity.

The MRH group surveyed their fellow students on issues of social justice as part of a presentation titled "The Photovoice Project."

Gateway2Change Student Summits on Race inspire and motivate young people to become leaders for positive change in their local community. This unique approach helps young people engage in purposeful conversations about the social and cultural differences that exist within the St. Louis region and create a plan to affect positive change.
